results.question: Which semesters can I take the Operating Systems course?
results.final_response:
At FIB, the **Operating Systems (SO)** course availability depends on your study program:

### **Bachelor's Degree (GRAU)**
The core **SO** (Operating Systems) course is offered in **both semesters**:
*   **Q1 (Autumn semester):** Classes are available in Catalan, Spanish, and English.
*   **Q2 (Spring semester):** Classes are available in Catalan and Spanish.

Other related bachelor's electives like **SO2** (Operating Systems II), **SOA** (Advanced Operating Systems), and **ASO** (Operating Systems Administration) are also generally available in both semesters.

### **Master's Degree (MIRI)**
The **OS-MIRI** course is specifically for the Master in Innovation and Research in Informatics and is only offered in:
*   **Q1 (Autumn semester)**

| Course Code | Name | Study Plan | Offered In |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **SO** | Operating Systems | Bachelor (GRAU) | Q1 & Q2 |
| **OS-MIRI** | Operating Systems | Master (MIRI) | Q1 only |
| **CASO** | Adv. Concepts on OS | Bachelor (GRAU) | Q2 only |
| **SOAD** | OS for Distributed Apps | Bachelor (GRAU) | Q2 only |

**Note:** As your profile does not specify a current study plan, these details cover the most common paths. If you are in a different program (like Data Science), please let me know

results.question: What AI-related courses are available in the bachelor's degree?
results.final_response:
The FIB Bachelor's Degree in Informatics Engineering (**GRAU**) offers several AI-related courses, primarily within the **Computing** specialization. These courses provide a comprehensive foundation in algorithms, data analysis, and intelligent systems.

### Core and Elective AI Courses in GRAU

| Code | Course Name | Credits | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **IA** | [Artificial Intelligence](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/IA) | 6 ECTS | The fundamental intro: state-space search, heuristics, and automated reasoning. |
| **APA** | [Machine Learning](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/APA) | 6 ECTS | Core algorithms for learning from data (classification, regression, and clustering). |
| **ECSDI** | [Knowledge Engineering](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/ECSDI) | 6 ECTS | Focuses on knowledge representation, expert systems, and multi-agent systems. |
| **MD** | [Data Mining](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/MD) | 6 ECTS | Techniques for discovering patterns and knowledge in large datasets. |
| **CAIM** | [Information Search](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/CAIM) | 6 ECTS | Massive information retrieval and large-scale web data analysis. |
| **VC** | [Computer Vision](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/VC) | 6 ECTS | Processing and interpreting visual information using computational methods. |
| **ROB** | [Robotics](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/ROB) | 6 ECTS | Basics of autonomous systems, including sensing, kinematics, and control. |

### Note on Advanced Topics
If you are specifically looking for **Deep Learning** or **Natural Language Processing (NLP)**, these are typically covered in detail at the Master's level (MAI). However, the **APA** and **VC** courses in the bachelor's degree often introduce the fundamental concepts required for these advanced topics.

Most of these courses are part of the **Computing (Computació)** specialization, so if you're planning your degree path, that is the area to focus on.

results.question: Tell me about the Machine Learning course at FIB
results.final_response:
Based on your current enrollment in the Master in Data Science (MDS) and Master in Artificial Intelligence (MAI) courses, there are two primary "Machine Learning" courses relevant to you.

The most direct match for your program is **ML-MDS**, which is typically taken in the second semester (Spring).

### Relevant Machine Learning Courses

| Code | Name | ECTS | Program | Semester |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **ML-MDS** | Machine Learning | 6 | Master in Data Science (MDS) | Spring (Q2) |
| **IML-MAI** | Introduction to Machine Learning | 5 | Master in Artificial Intelligence (MAI) | Fall (Q1) |

---

### **ML-MDS: Machine Learning** (Most Relevant)
Since you are already taking *Data Analysis and Knowledge Discovery* (**DAKD-MDS**), this is the standard follow-up or companion course in your curriculum.

*   **Schedule**: This is a **Spring (Q2)** semester course.
*   **Professors**: Marta Arias Vicente and Ignasi Gómez Sebastià.
*   **Evaluation**: Typically involves a **Partial exam** (April) and a **Final exam** (June), supplemented by practical lab assignments.
*   **Syllabus**: Covers core ML paradigms, including supervised and unsupervised learning, specifically tailored for data science applications. [Full Syllabus](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/masters/master-data-science/curriculum/syllabus/ML-MDS).

### **Other Versions**
If you are looking for information on different levels:
*   **APA (Machine Learning)**: The core 6-ECTS course for the **Informatics Engineering Bachelor's** (GRAU).
*   **AA1 / AA2**: Two sequential courses for the **Data Science and Engineering Bachelor's** (GCED).
*   **AML-MDS**: Advanced Machine Learning, for those who have already completed the basics.

**Note:** If you are planning your enrollment for the next semester, keep in mind that **ML-MDS** is a Spring course, while **IML-MAI** is usually a Fall course.

results.question: What networking courses are available?
results.final_response:
FIB offers several courses related to networking, ranging from foundational bachelor's subjects to advanced master's specializations.

### Bachelor's Degree Courses (GRAU, BBI, GIA)
These courses cover the fundamentals of computer networks, distributed systems, and specific applications like neural networks.

| Code | Course Name | ECTS | Study Plan |
|:---|:---|:---:|:---|
| **XC** | Computer Networks | 6 | GRAU |
| **XC2** | Computer Networks II | 6 | GRAU |
| **TXC** | Computer Network Technology | 6 | GRAU |
| **SDX** | Distributed Network Systems | 6 | GRAU |
| **XNDL-GIA** | Neural Networks and Deep Learning | 6 | GIA |
| **NSB-BBI** | Networks and Systems Biology | 6 | BBI |

### Master's Degree Courses (MIRI, MAI, MDS, MEI)
Specialized courses focusing on advanced architectures, internet technologies, and complex network analysis.

| Code | Course Name | ECTS | Study Plan |
|:---|:---|:---:|:---|
| **CNANM-MIRI** | Computer Network Architectures and Management | 6 | MIRI |
| **FINE-MIRI** | Future Internet Networks | 6 | MIRI |
| **CSN-MIRI** | Complex and Social Networks | 6 | MIRI, MEI, MDS |
| **SANS-MIRI** | Statistical Analysis of Networks and Systems | 6 | MIRI |
| **SNM-MIRI** | Stochastic Network Modelling | 6 | MIRI |
| **CN-MAI** | Complex Networks | 5 | MAI |

**Common Starting Point:**
If you are looking for the core networking sequence in the Bachelor's degree (GRAU), **XC** (Computer Networks) is the introductory course, followed by **XC2** for more advanced topics.

Which program are you currently enrolled in or interested in? I can provide more specific details on the syllabus or prerequisites for any of these.

results.question: Compare PRO1 and PRO2 courses
results.final_response:
PRO1 (Programming I) and PRO2 (Programming II) are the two foundational programming courses in the FIB Bachelor's Degree in Informatics Engineering (GRAU). They are designed as a sequence to take students from absolute beginners to proficient programmers.

### At a Glance

| Feature | PRO1 (Programming I) | PRO2 (Programming II) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Course Code** | PRO1 | PRO2 |
| **Credits** | 7.5 ECTS | 7.5 ECTS |
| **Year/Semester** | 1st Year / 1st Semester (Q1) | 1st Year / 2nd Semester (Q2) |
| **Primary Focus** | Algorithmic thinking & Imperative programming | Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) & Data Structures |
| **Language** | C++ | C++ |

---

### Key Differences

#### 1. Programming Paradigm
*   **PRO1** focuses on **imperative programming**. You learn how to give the computer a sequence of instructions to solve a problem.
*   **PRO2** introduces **Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)**. Instead of just functions and variables, you learn to organize code into classes and objects, focusing on encapsulation and modularity.

#### 2. Technical Content
*   **PRO1 Topics:** Basic syntax, control structures (loops, if-else), functions, recursion, and basic data sequences like vectors.
*   **PRO2 Topics:** Classes, linear data structures (stacks, queues, lists), non-linear structures (trees), and advanced use of the C++ Standard Template Library (STL).

#### 3. Progression
*   **PRO1** is about learning "how to code"—the logic behind algorithms and basic problem-solving.
*   **PRO2** is about "how to design software"—organizing complex code efficiently and choosing the right data structures for the job.

### Prerequisites
*   **PRO1** has no prerequisites and assumes no prior programming knowledge.
*   **PRO2** technically requires the knowledge from PRO1. While the system may allow enrollment, it is extremely difficult to pass PRO2 without a solid grasp of PRO1 concepts (especially recursion and pointers).

### Relevant Links
*   [PRO1 Official Syllabus](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/PRO1)
*   [PRO2 Official Syllabus](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/PRO2)

results.question: What international study opportunities are available?
results.final_response:
FIB offers several international study opportunities that are particularly relevant for you as a Master's student (enrolled in MDS/MAI courses). Since it is currently January 7, 2026, the **main application call for the 2026-2027 academic year is approaching in February**.

### 1. Key Mobility Programs

*   **Erasmus+ Studies (Europe):** The most common exchange program. It includes a monthly grant and covers universities across Europe. Popular destinations for Informatics include **KTH** (Sweden), **TU Munich** (Germany), and **TU Delft** (Netherlands).
*   **Double Degrees:** As a Master's student, you can earn two degrees—one from UPC and one from a partner institution. FIB has strong agreements with:
    *   **KTH Royal Institute of Technology** (Stockholm, Sweden)
    *   **IMT** (France)
    *   **Politecnico di Milano** (Italy)
*   **UPC-Global (Outside Europe):** Exchanges with universities in the USA, Canada, Asia (like **National University of Singapore**), and Australia. These typically require a higher GPA and earlier preparation.
*   **Erasmus+ Traineeships:** If you prefer practical experience, you can receive a grant to do an internship or your Master's Thesis (TFM) at a company or research lab in Europe.

### 2. Immediate Opportunities & Deadlines

| Opportunity | Application Period | Target Period |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Main Mobility Call** | **February 2026** | Academic Year 2026-2027 |
| **Aalto Summer Research** | **Open Now** | Summer 2026 |
| **Secondary Call** | Sept - Oct 2026 | Spring 2027 |

results.question: Tell me everything about the EDA course
results.final_response:
**EDA** (Estructures de Dades i Algorismes / Data Structures and Algorithmics) is one of the most fundamental courses at FIB. While it is primarily a core subject for the Bachelor's Degree in Informatics Engineering (GRAU), its concepts are essential for all computer science disciplines.

Given that you are currently enrolled in Master's courses (MDS and MAI), you might be interested in the Bachelor version (EDA) as a prerequisite or its Master's equivalent, **ADSDB-MDS**.

### **EDA: Estructures de Dades i Algorismes (Bachelor - GRAU)**

*   **Course Code:** EDA (UPC: 270012)
*   **Credits:** 6 ECTS
*   **Language:** Offered in English, Catalan, and Spanish (Q1); Catalan and Spanish (Q2).
*   **Description:** The course focuses on designing and implementing efficient data structures and algorithms. You will learn about complexity analysis, advanced trees, graphs, and algorithmic paradigms like recursion and greedy algorithms.

#### **Upcoming Exams (2025-2026 Q1)**
| Date | Time | Type | Room(s) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Jan 9, 2026** | 14:00 / 17:00 | Lab Exam | A5S102, A5S108, C6S302, etc. |
| **Jan 14, 2026** | 15:00 - 18:00 | Theory Final | A5001, A5002, A6001, etc. |

#### **Main Professors**
- **Conrado Martínez Parra** (conrado@cs.upc.edu)
- **Albert Oliveras Llunell** (oliveras@cs.upc.edu)
- **Salvador Roura Ferret** (roura@cs.upc.edu)

---

### **Master's Equivalent: ADSDB-MDS**
Since you are in the **Master in Data Science (MDS)** program, the equivalent course in your curriculum is **ADSDB** (Algorithms, Data Structures and Databases).

*   **Course Code:** ADSDB-MDS
*   **Credits:** 6 ECTS
*   **Focus:** Tailored for data science, it covers algorithms and data structures with a heavier emphasis on large-scale data management and database systems.

results.question: Plan my exam week: I'm taking IA, EDA, and BD
results.final_response:
Here is your exam schedule and a recommended study plan for the upcoming week.

### **Exam Schedule: January 2026**

| Date | Time | Course | Classrooms |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Mon, Jan 12** | 15:00 – 18:00 | **BD** (Databases) | A5001, A5002, A5103, A5104, A5E01, A6001, A6002 |
| **Wed, Jan 14** | 11:30 – 14:30 | **IA** (Artificial Intelligence) | A5001, A5002 |
| **Wed, Jan 14** | 15:00 – 18:00 | **EDA** (Data Structures & Alg.) | A5001, A5002, A5E01, A5E02, A6001, A6002, A6E01 |

**⚠️ Warning:** Note that **IA** and **EDA** are scheduled on the same day (Wednesday, Jan 14) with only a **30-minute break** between them. This will be a high-intensity day, so mental preparation and snacks are essential!

---

### **Recommended Study Plan**

Since today is Wednesday, Jan 7, you have 5 full days before your first exam.

| Day | Priority | Morning (9:00 - 13:00) | Afternoon (14:30 - 18:30) | Evening (20:00 - 22:00) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Wed, Jan 7** | IA / EDA | IA: Machine Learning/Search | EDA: Trees & Graphs | Review IA/EDA logic |
| **Thu, Jan 8** | BD | Relational Algebra & SQL | SQL Practice & Normalization | BD Theory quiz |
| **Fri, Jan 9** | BD | Transaction Mgmt / Concurrency | BD Past Exams | BD Quick Review |
| **Sat, Jan 10** | IA / EDA | IA: Logic & Planning | EDA: Sorting & D&C | Light IA Review |
| **Sun, Jan 11** | BD / IA | **BD: Final Review (Pre-exam)** | IA: Final Mock Exam | Relax & Early Sleep |
| **Mon, Jan 12** | **BD Exam** | Light BD formulas review | **BD EXAM (15:00)** | Rest & EDA Review |
| **Tue, Jan 13** | IA & EDA | IA: Mock Exam / Key Concepts | EDA: Mock Exam / Key Concepts | Final formula sheet check |
| **Wed, Jan 14** | **IA & EDA** | **IA EXAM (11:30)** | **EDA EXAM (15:00)** | **Post-exam celebration!** |

### **Key Tips for Success**
*   **The Wednesday Crunch:** Since you have two exams back-to-back on Jan 14, prioritize doing full mock exams for IA and EDA this weekend to build up your "exam stamina."
*   **Database Practice:** For BD, the best way to study is by writing SQL queries by hand to ensure you don't rely on auto-complete.
*   **EDA Visuals:** Practice drawing out the state of data structures (Heaps, AVL trees, B-Trees) after specific operations; this is a common exam requirement.
*   **Logistics:** Check your specific classroom assignment on the FIB website or the RACÓ notices, as these exams use multiple large rooms.

Good luck with your exams! Let me know if you need specific details about any of these courses.

results.question: What are my options for elective courses next semester?

Since you are taking courses from both the **Master in Data Science (MDS)** and the **Master in Artificial Intelligence (MAI)**, I have categorized the options by program and highlighted those that best complement your current studies.

### 🌟 Recommended for You
These courses are direct continuations or highly relevant to what you are studying now:

*   **Advanced Human Language Technologies (AHLT-MAI)**: The natural next step after HLE-MAI, focusing on state-of-the-art NLP and semantic analysis. (5 ECTS)
*   **Algorithmics for Data Mining (ADM-MIRI)**: Complements DAKD-MDS by focusing on the advanced algorithms needed for large-scale data analysis. (6 ECTS)
*   **Data Visualization (VD-MDS)**: Essential for presenting the findings from the data analysis techniques you're learning in DAKD. (6 ECTS)

| Code | Name | ECTS | Description |
| :--- | :--- | :---: | :--- |

| **AHLT-MAI** | Advanced Human Languages Tech | 5 | Deep dive into modern NLP and sequence modeling. |

results.question: What are the job prospects for computer science graduates in Barcelona?
results.final_response:
Job prospects for Computer Science graduates in Barcelona are exceptionally strong. The city has cemented itself as a **top-tier European tech hub**, currently ranked as the 5th most digitized region in Europe and a leading startup ecosystem (surpassing many larger capitals in startup density).

Here is a breakdown of the current landscape for 2024–2025:

### 1. Market Overview & Major Hubs
Barcelona is home to over **2,300 startups** and numerous international "tech hubs." The heart of this activity is the **22@ District** (Poblenou), where many global giants have established their digital headquarters.

*   **International Tech Hubs:** Companies like **Microsoft, Amazon, Oracle (NetSuite & Oracle Health), Dynatrace, MongoDB, and HP** have large engineering centers in the city.
*   **Local Unicorns & Scale-ups:** Barcelona has produced several "unicorns" (startups valued over $1B) that are major employers, including **Glovo, TravelPerk, Wallapop, and Factorial**.
*   **Sector Diversity:** While E-commerce and FinTech are dominant, there is a massive surge in **AI, HealthTech, and GreenTech**.

### 2. Salary Expectations
Salaries in Barcelona are competitive within the Spanish market, though they remain lower than in hubs like Zurich or London. However, the cost of living is also generally lower, and the quality of life is a significant draw.

| Level | Estimated Annual Salary (Gross) |
| :--- | :--- |
| **Junior / Entry-level** | €28,000 – €36,000 |
| **Mid-level (3–5 years)** | €40,000 – €55,000 |
| **Senior / Lead** | €60,000 – €90,000+ |
| **Specialized (AI/Data/Security)** | €70,000 – €120,000+ |

### 3. Most In-Demand Skills
The "Digital Spain 2025" initiative is driving massive investment in specific areas:
*   **Software Engineering:** Java (Spring Boot), Python, and JavaScript (React/Node.js) remain the core requirements.
*   **Data & AI:** High demand for Data Engineers and Machine Learning Engineers due to the growing AI hub in Catalonia.
*   **Cloud & DevOps:** Proficiency in AWS, Azure, and Kubernetes is highly valued as companies migrate to cloud-native architectures.
*   **Cybersecurity:** A critical shortage of talent has made this one of the highest-paying niches.

### 4. FIB-Specific Advantages
As a FIB (UPC) student, you have a significant advantage in the local market:
*   **FIB Visiona:** The faculty’s annual career fair is one of the best ways to meet recruiters from companies like **Bloomberg, NTT Data, Accenture, and HP** directly on campus.
*   **Internships (Convenis):** FIB has strong ties with local industry, allowing you to gain experience at top companies while finishing your degree, often leading to a full-time offer.
*   **Reputation:** UPC is consistently ranked as one of the best technical universities in Southern Europe, and a degree from FIB is highly respected by local and international recruiters.

### Tips for Success
1.  **English is Mandatory:** While Catalan and Spanish are important for social life, almost all high-growth tech companies in Barcelona operate in English.
2.  **Network at Events:** Attend meetups at places like **Barcelona Activa** or the **Pier01 (Tech Barcelona)** hub.
3.  **Use FIB Resources:** Keep an eye on the "Notices" section of your FIB account for company presentations and job offers specifically for UPC students.

results.question: How does FIB compare to other CS schools in Europe?
results.final_response:
The **Barcelona School of Informatics (FIB)** at the Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC) is consistently recognized as one of the top institutions for Computer Science in Europe and the premier school in Spain.

Here is how FIB compares to other European CS schools based on rankings, reputation, and its ecosystem:

### 1. International Rankings (2025-2026)
FIB/UPC typically ranks in the **Top 10–30 in Europe** for Computer Science and Information Systems, placing it in the same tier as elite technical universities like KTH (Sweden), TU Berlin (Germany), and Politecnico di Milano (Italy).

*   **In Spain:** Consistently ranked **#1 or #2** (often competing with the University of Granada).
*   **In Europe:**
    *   **QS World University Rankings:** Generally ranks between **15th and 25th** in Europe for Computer Science.
    *   **US News & World Report:** Often places UPC in the **Top 10** in Europe for specifically "Computer Science" research output.
    *   **Times Higher Education (THE):** Consistently in the **top 100 globally**, which translates to a top-tier position in Europe.

### 2. Strategic Peer Comparison
While the absolute "top" of European CS is dominated by **ETH Zurich**, **Oxford**, **EPFL**, **TU Munich**, and **TU Delft**, FIB is widely considered the leading Southern European alternative.

| Feature | FIB (UPC) | Top Tier Peers (ETH, TUM, Delft) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Specialization** | Strong focus on High-Performance Computing (BSC) and AI. | Very broad; heavy focus on Robotics and Aero-Informatics. |
| **Industry Ties** | Strongest in Spain; local hub for Southern Europe. | Global industry ties (Google, Microsoft, Siemens). |
| **Cost** | Public tuition (approx. €2,000–€4,000/year for EU). | Varies; TUM is now introducing fees for non-EU; ETH is low. |
| **Research Hub** | Home to the **MareNostrum** Supercomputer. | Massive internal research budgets. |

### 3. Key Strengths of FIB
*   **The Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC):** Located on the same campus, the BSC houses **MareNostrum**, one of the most powerful supercomputers in the world. This provides FIB students and researchers with world-class opportunities in parallel computing and data science.
*   **Innovation & History:** Founded in 1977, FIB was a pioneer of informatics education in Spain. It is known for a rigorous, engineering-focused curriculum that is highly respected by technical recruiters.
*   **Tech Ecosystem:** Barcelona is the **#1 startup hub in Southern Europe**. The school’s proximity to the **22@ tech district** means students have direct access to companies like Amazon, Microsoft, and Glovo, as well as hundreds of deep-tech startups.

### 4. International Programs
FIB is a key member of several elite European networks:
*   **EIT Digital:** Offers double-degree Master's programs with other top European schools (e.g., TU Berlin, KTH, UNS).
*   **ERASMUS+:** It has one of the most extensive exchange networks in Europe, with over 100 partner universities.

### Summary
FIB is a **top-tier European technical school**. While it may have slightly less "global brand name" recognition than ETH Zurich or Oxford, it is an academic powerhouse in **AI, Supercomputing, and Software Engineering**. For students looking for high-quality technical education within a world-class tech hub and a more affordable Mediterranean lifestyle, it is often the top choice in Europe.

results.question: What programming languages should I learn for AI?
results.final_response:
For a student at FIB, especially considering your current enrollment in the **Master in Data Science (MDS)** and **Master in Artificial Intelligence (MAI)**, the choice of programming languages is quite clear.

### 1. Python (The Essential)
Python is the undisputed leader in AI and the primary language for your current courses.
*   **Relevance to your courses:** In **HLE-MAI** (Human Language Engineering), Python is the standard for NLP (Natural Language Processing) using libraries like Hugging Face, NLTK, or SpaCy. In **DAKD-MDS**, it's the go-to for data processing.
*   **Why learn it:** It has the most mature ecosystem (PyTorch, TensorFlow, Scikit-learn) and is used for everything from rapid prototyping to deploying large-scale LLMs.

### 2. R (The Statistical Powerhouse)
As an MDS student, R is likely a significant part of your curriculum.
*   **Relevance to your courses:** **BSG-MDS** (Bioinformatics and Statistical Genetics) and **DAKD-MDS** (Data Analysis and Knowledge Discovery) often rely on R for its superior statistical modeling and data visualization capabilities (ggplot2, Bioconductor).
*   **Why learn it:** It remains the industry standard for academic research and advanced statistical analysis in fields like bioinformatics.

### 3. C++ (The Performance Layer)
While not always used in high-level AI research, C++ is critical for the "under the hood" operations.
*   **Use case:** If you are interested in **Computer Vision**, **Robotics**, or building the actual AI frameworks themselves (like the core of TensorFlow/PyTorch), C++ is essential for performance and memory management.
*   **At FIB:** It is used in more hardware-oriented or performance-critical courses in the GEI (Bachelor's) or specialized Master's modules.

### 4. Julia (The Rising Star)
Julia is gaining traction in scientific computing.
*   **Why learn it:** It aims to combine the speed of C++ with the ease of Python. It is excellent for heavy numerical simulations and optimization problems.

### 5. Prolog (The Logic Foundation)
*   **At FIB:** If you haven't taken it already, the **IA** (Artificial Intelligence) course in the Bachelor's degree uses Prolog.
*   **Why learn it:** It is useful for understanding symbolic AI, logic programming, and knowledge representation, which are different from the statistical machine learning dominating the field today.

---

### Summary Table for your Profile

| Language | Priority | Usage in Your Program (MDS/MAI) | Recommended Libraries |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Python** | **High** | NLP (HLE), Data Analysis (DAKD), ML | PyTorch, Scikit-learn, Transformers |
| **R** | **High** | Bioinformatics (BSG), Statistics | Tidyverse, Bioconductor, Caret |
| **C++** | Medium | High-performance AI, Computer Vision | OpenCV, CUDA |
| **Julia** | Low | Numerical Optimization | Flux.jl, DifferentialEquations.jl |

**My Recommendation:** Focus heavily on mastering **Python** for your NLP and general AI work, while ensuring you are proficient in **R** for your bioinformatics and statistical analysis. If you want to stand out in the job market for AI engineering roles, learning **C++** for performance optimization is a strong secondary skill.

results.question: Is APC hard?
results.final_response:
Whether **APC (PC Architecture)** is "hard" depends on your strengths, but it is generally considered a technically focused course with a significant practical workload.

Here is an objective breakdown to help you gauge the difficulty:

### 1. Evaluation Style: Project-Based
One of the most important things to note about APC is that it **does not have formal partial or final exams** in the standard FIB exam calendar. 
*   **Meaning:** The course likely follows a **continuous evaluation** model.
*   **Difficulty Factor:** Instead of studying for one big exam, your grade will depend on **projects and laboratory assignments**. This means a steady workload throughout the semester rather than a single crunch period, which many students find more manageable but time-consuming.

### 2. Technical Focus
The course is managed by the **Computer Architecture (AC)** department. At FIB, AC courses are known for being detail-oriented. You will likely deal with:
*   Processor architectures and performance optimization.
*   Memory hierarchy (Cache, RAM) and how hardware interacts with software.
*   System buses and I/O subsystems.

### 3. Course Profile
*   **Level:** It is a 5th-semester (3rd year) elective for the Bachelor in Informatics (GRAU) and Data Science (GCED).
*   **Credits:** 6 ECTS (Standard workload of ~150-180 hours).
*   **Teaching Team:** It is currently taught by a small team (often just **Professor Daniel Naro**), which usually allows for more direct interaction but also means the course follows a very specific vision.

### Summary for your Context
As you are currently enrolled in **Master's programs (MDS/MAI)**:
*   **If you enjoy low-level systems:** You might find the concepts straightforward, but don't underestimate the time required for the lab projects.
*   **If you prefer high-level data analysis:** The transition to hardware-centric logic and low-level performance metrics might feel like a significant shift in thinking.

**Conclusion:** It is not considered a "filter" course (like the notoriously difficult early-degree subjects), but it requires **consistent dedication to the projects** to succeed. 

You can find the full syllabus and more details [here](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/APC).

results.question: What's the difference between GRAU and GCED programs?
results.final_response:
The **GRAU** (Grau en Enginyeria Informàtica) and **GCED** (Grau en Ciència i Enginyeria de Dades) are the two primary bachelor's programs at FIB. While they share a foundation in programming and algorithms, they have distinct goals and technical focuses.

### **Quick Comparison**

| Feature | **GRAU** (Informatics Engineering) | **GCED** (Data Science & Engineering) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Primary Goal** | Building and managing software and hardware systems. | Extracting insights and knowledge from data. |
| **Core Skills** | Software architecture, networks, systems, hardware. | Machine learning, advanced statistics, modeling. |
| **Mathematics** | Foundational (Calculus, Algebra, Discrete). | Intensive (Optimization, Probability, Statistics). |
| **Specialization** | Choose 1 of 5 "Mencions" (e.g., Software, Computing). | Specialized from the start in the Data cycle. |
| **Duration** | 4 years (240 ECTS) | 4 years (240 ECTS) |

---

### **Key Curriculum Differences**

*   **Engineering vs. Analysis**: 
    *   **GRAU** is a classical Computer Science degree. You learn how a computer works from the transistor level up to complex distributed web applications. It includes mandatory courses in **Operating Systems, Computer Architecture, and Networks**.
    *   **GCED** is built on the intersection of **Mathematics and Computing**. It focuses on the mathematical tools needed to process and interpret massive datasets. You will take more advanced courses in **Statistics, Optimization, and Signal Processing**.
*   **System Design vs. Modeling**:
    *   In **GRAU**, you focus on *how to build it* (e.g., How do I make this software scalable and secure?).
    *   In **GCED**, you focus on *what the data says* (e.g., How do I build a model to predict these trends?).

### **Career Paths**

*   **GRAU Graduates** typically become:
    *   Software Engineers / Full-stack Developers
    *   Systems Architects
    *   DevOps & Cloud Specialists
    *   Project Managers
*   **GCED Graduates** typically become:
    *   Data Scientists
    *   Machine Learning Engineers
    *   Data Analysts
    *   Big Data Architects

**Summary**: If you are more interested in the **construction of technology** and software systems, **GRAU** is the better fit. If you are more interested in **applied mathematics** and using algorithms to solve data-driven problems, **GCED** is for you.

results.question: Can you recommend courses for someone interested in cybersecurity?
results.final_response:
FIB offers several courses focusing on different aspects of cybersecurity, ranging from foundational computer security to advanced cryptography and management.

### Recommended Courses

| Code | Course Name | ECTS | Program | Focus |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **SI** | [**Computer Security**](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/SI) | 6 | GRAU | Fundamentals of protection, threats, and security mechanisms. |
| **GCS** | [**Cybersecurity Management**](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/GCS) | 6 | GRAU/GIA/GCED | Organizational security, risk management, and compliance. |
| **C** | [**Cryptography**](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/C) | 6 | GRAU/GIA/GCED | Mathematical foundations, encryption algorithms, and protocols. |
| **CCQ** | [**Quantum Computing & Crypto**](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/bachelors-degrees/bachelor-degree-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/CCQ) | 6 | GRAU/GIA | Future-facing security in the context of quantum computing. |
| **IAS-MIRI** | [**Internet Applications & Security**](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/masters/master-innovation-and-research-informatics/curriculum/syllabus/IAS-MIRI) | 6 | MIRI (Master) | Advanced security for web and network applications. |
| **ISDCM** | [**Internet & Security Distribution**](https://www.fib.upc.edu/en/studies/masters/master-informatics-engineering/curriculum/syllabus/ISDCM-MEI) | 6 | MEI (Master) | Network security and secure content distribution. |

### Suggested Path
1.  **If you are a Bachelor's student (GRAU):** Start with **SI (Computer Security)** to get a broad overview. If you enjoy the math behind it, take **C (Cryptography)**. If you are more interested in the organizational side, choose **GCS (Cybersecurity Management)**.
2.  **If you are a Master's student:** Look into **IAS-MIRI** or **ISDCM** for more specialized and technical security topics.

Are you currently enrolled in a specific program? I can help you check if any of these courses fit into your current curriculum or elective options.
